user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_dev_close:
```c
static void metal_linux_dev_close(struct metal_bus *bus,
				  struct metal_device *device)
{
	struct linux_device *ldev = to_linux_device(device);
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);

	ldev->ldrv->dev_close(lbus, ldev);
	metal_list_del(&device->node);
	free(ldev);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_linux_dev_close:
static struct linux_device *to_linux_device(struct metal_device *device)
{
	return metal_container_of(device, struct linux_device, device);
}
...
static struct linux_bus *to_linux_bus(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	return metal_container_of(bus, struct linux_bus, bus);
}
...
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
...
struct linux_bus {
	struct metal_bus	bus;
	const char		*bus_name;
	struct linux_driver	drivers[MAX_DRIVERS];
	struct sysfs_bus	*sbus;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
free(ldev);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The free(ldev) statement is reachable in normal control flow: ldev is obtained from the input device, ldrv->dev_close(lbus, ldev) is an ordinary callback expected to return, then metal_list_del executes and free(ldev) runs. Therefore the shown code does not contain unreachable code. A specific violation scenario would be if ldrv->dev_close is implemented or annotated as a non‑returning function (e.g. it calls exit/abort or has the noreturn attribute) or otherwise never returns; in that case free(ldev) would be unreachable and rule 2.1 would be violated.
